question: I haven't known for long. I just decided. What do I need that makes me make these decisions?
answer: You got me. What does Beth say?

question: I know this place. I know what happens here. I know what's going to happen. The same job, same scenery, same people... I've been in this town for years... Years!!
How long a drive is it?
That's not bad.
answer: In a car? It's a fuckin' nightmare. And there's no radio in Utah. It's all religious programs.

question: Hey. Think about this. You take a detour and go through Vegas -- you and Beth stop, see a show, have a nice romantic dinner -- play the slots, get the free drinks...
answer: Too much money. The show. The meal. The slots. Then the hotel -- that's another hundred down the toilet.

question: I'm tired. I'm going to bed.
I haven't got a problem.
answer: Okay. You agreed to try Billings.

question: I know. Billings, Montana. City of the future.
answer: Yeah and I read that a while ago -- so the future's probably already there. It's not like you're leaving anything behind. A good job or something.

question: I know. I'm not eight years old. I know I'll make new friends.
I, umm... I... It embarrasses me. When you talk about something with Carol that happened before me. She's my best friend. It embarrasses me that you used to live with her.
I know...
answer: And we're moving. She won't be your best friend anymore. Living with someone isn't such a big deal. Anyway... I live with you now. Beth!... Beth!! It's... it's raining!

question: Water comes out.
answer: Shit. I hate this shit! It never kept the coffee hot. And now this.

question: It still works.
answer: No. It doesn't. Water comes out.

question: Okay.
answer: I could've gotten a new one. On my discount. Now it's too late.

question: Do you want a donut?
answer: No. I want an appliance that works. This coffee maker was junk. This blender's junk. Our t.v. is junk! I don't know why we're even bothering to pack.

question: And it's fifteen inch.
answer: I can't believe we don't have a big t.v.

question: I say do it. Sears can afford to give you a bonus.
What do you mean?
answer: Maybe when I get my check today, there'll be a bonus in it.

question: There's no bonus.
answer: Yeah... That's true. And I sold a lot of teevees for them...

question: You should take a t.v.
answer: I should go. Don't wanna be late on my last day.

question: Mmmmm...
answer: I gotta go. Just waiting for the last second to put on the noose. So Chip -- what's new?

question: I gotta go. Just waiting for the last second to put on the noose. So Chip -- what's new?
answer: Nothing much. I heard you're leaving.

question: I was gonna quit anyway -- this way I get unemployment.
Yeah... recession insurance... This way I'm not stuck waiting around for the lay-offs to start.
You...
answer: Sid. Nice to see you again.

question: Why are you here?
answer: Realty office likes a fresh coat between tenants.

question: We're still here.
answer: I've done this house before. I did a nice job.

question: Yeah...?
answer: The new people move in on Sunday. Where are you moving to?

question: It can't be worse than Enfield, Arizona.
answer: I've lived in Enfield my whole life. Could you hold this? I use this to mask. Have you ever used masking tape to mask?

question: No. I haven't.
answer: A house like this, it's real easy. Hardly needs a paint job.

question: You can skip it. I won't tell.
answer: It needs a fresh coat... ...a little color.

question: What color is it gonna be?
It's already off-white.
answer: No. It's white. It's just dirty. Now if it was my house, I would choose a color... I would not choose off-white.

question: What would you choose?
answer: The color of your eyes. Hazel.

question: Sorry I'm late, the new girl's a moron.
I thought you might need it.
answer: I do! I had a map -- I lost it.

question: Let's highlight your route. Here's Enfield.
answer: Here's Billings. Look at this -- right there -- that's the town I was born in. Where I grew up. Where my parent's live... Isn't that a coincidence?

question: You're going to be driving by.
answer: No... They're not near the interstate. I haven't even called them in years.

question: You might as well visit.
answer: No. I wouldn't know them. Shit.

question: I'm lucky I don't have to kill them.
If they were dark, I'd have to put a layer of kill down first. So the dark paint wouldn't shine through the off-white.
It covers the old paint so that you'd never know it was there, but it gives off fumes when it's drying. Noxious fumes. They would find us on the floor unconscious.
...unconscious.
answer: Nick. The man I live with.

question: I guess he'd be the "they".
answer: He'd find us. And he'd be surprised.

question: It was the drive that killed us. San Antonio to Seattle is just too many hours in a car. If we'd have flown, we would've made it.
Things were all right in bed.
answer: But the rest of the time they were... awful.

question: Really?
answer: Nick. We couldn't stand each other. We stopped in Enfield and just stayed.

question: Why didn't you go on to Seattle? It was your car.
I'm done in there. I won't paint the ceiling 'til you've moved the furniture out.
answer: I don't think we're going to take much of the furniture.

question: I kind of like the sofa.
You're not going to take it?
He says yes. We've got to talk.
It's making the rounds. College students use it.
Which is your career?
answer: Painting. I'm an inside person. Mowing grass is seasonal.

question: I work on it.
answer: Do you want to get stoned?

question: Yeah.
answer: This kind of painting -- for people I won't know -- it's boring. It's not very good. It's homegrown.

question: Yeah?
answer: But it'll get you fucked up.

question: takes a drag on the joint like an old pro.
I own an American set. I'm very satisfied.
I'll tell you... ...the thing is, a hundred and fifty dollars gets you very little in the way of Japanese technology.
It would get you that t.v.
Your parents?
answer: Yes. They live with me... ...and they want Japanese. Is there a problem?

question: No... I, uh, just never think of adults as having parents.
I know... I'm an adult, I have parents. Oh, Miss, I've got your receipt!
Now you just take this receipt out, give it to the guys at the loading dock and they'll give you your brand new beautiful television set.
Out back. They'll help load it in your car and everything.
Out back. Think about American. They're mostly Japanese parts anyway.
Miss... I'm helping this customer here, perhaps you might... You might want to see someone else.
Excellent.
answer: Maybe I should just leave it packed...

question: C'mon! You stole it. You gotta see it! Hold the box. Wait! I thought I heard the police.
Me?
answer: You're being silly and you've got bunny eyes.

question: I'm a little stoned... not that stoned.
Very stoned.
answer: I didn't think she liked you.

question: She doesn't. But she likes getting stoned.
There's nothing like drugs to create a quick and shallow friendship. Let's look at the loot. Jesus... you didn't fool around.
answer: This is the nicest thing I've ever owned. It's a beautiful picture.

question: Come see!
answer: I should have had him steal me one, too.

question: Forget it... How's the painting going?
answer: Too many distractions. I'll be at it all night.

question: You have bad work habits.
answer: Not when I'm actually working. I better get set up in the kitchen.

question: It makes teevee seem very futuristic.
Thank you. Shit. Missed the eye, got the face.
Wait a second. He really wants to get in your pants.
answer: My pants are taken. Why don't you go for him?

question: He likes you.
answer: I wish Nick would get back and help with the packing. He's probably getting drunk with the stockboys... That's what he's probably doing.

question: I'll help.
answer: I've got to be out of here Sunday. That's tomorrow.

question: You can come to my place.
Nobody lives in that, right?
answer: Gift shop. But it closed at seven.

question: I got no one to shop for. Shit. Fuckin' wind...
What does it mean?
answer: High pressure field coming in -- should bring some nice weather.

question: No. The wind itself, you know what I mean, you're an Indian...
Yeah, so you're in tune with this stuff...

Oh... right. Here's a twenty. So what does the wind mean? Like as an omen or something, you know -- -- a change is coming to the people. -- the spirit of freedom is walking the land. That kind of meaning...
answer: Fourteen, fifteen and five makes twenty. The wind is. It's the wind like I'm a Navajo.

question: He said he needs to be alone again. Learn about himself. Make a fresh start in a new town. He's sorry. He said he would have called you, but your phone's disconnected. 'Cause you're moving. He's always been an asshole. You'll be all right.
I'm here.
answer: I know that. Oh... uh, no...

question: You've lived here your whole life?
You've never gone anywhere?
answer: Travelling has no allure for me.

question: Why?
answer: It's my home. I belong here.

question: I'm serious.
answer: My father says if you stay in one place long enough your luck knows where to find you.

question: Thanks. You think your father knows the truth?
answer: He's a bartender. He's lived here his whole life.

question: Has his luck found him?
answer: Not yet. But it's probably very close. Are you all right?

question: Must be the paint fumes... You find what you want here?
Oh. No...
answer: We never met before last night... ...but we know each other.

question: It's not.
answer: Come hold me. Come hold me, and you'll be happy.

question: I'll find happiness. Right. In your arms.
But I won't. I have to find happiness in myself.
answer: No. That's wrong. People tell you that, but it's wrong. I've lived with people who have that happiness from within. That happiness -- it's just them being pleased with themselves. It's not enough. It's a lonely thing.

question: You're showing how young you are.
answer: No. I'm not. I'm showing you a way. You know that. And you know me. And I know you.

question: I know you want to fuck me.
I know... I know you. I know you.
Excuse me... Excuse me... I'm... I'm looking for my parents. My mother, my father... they... Hello.
Oh... good... This is my house. I, uhh... mean this is the house I grew up in.
My name is Nick, Nick Brennan. Did you know the Brennans?
They lived here. They used to live here. I used to live here with them... What's your name?
I know an Elizabeth. I call her Beth. This is a good sandwich.
When did he move here? Would he know where the people before him went?
I've lost my parents.
answer: Did you lose them both at the same time?

question: Then yes. I lost them both at the same time.
answer: I lost mine one at a time. Last year.

question: I'm sorry. That's tragic. I should...
answer: Six months apart. Body failures. Separate body failures.

question: I'm really sorry. I should go.
answer: First my father's heart kept starting and stopping.

question: Attacks...
answer: My mother and I were with him in the hospital and he'd grab at us, he'd grab my arms and hold on.

question: That's very sad... I've really gotta be going. I, uh... thank you again for the sandwich. Delicious...
answer: Right before my mother died, she said -- "Elizabeth. You're adopted."

question: Have you found your real parents?
answer: No. Two are enough to lose. I'm not alone. I have my Grandfather.

question: I'd like to stay right here...
answer: I have to be out tomorrow.

question: In this moment... Enjoying this moment.
It can go on as long as we want.
answer: Have you ever been in a relationship?

question: No. I was married... but it wasn't really a relationship.
Two years. Right out of high school.
answer: Do I remind you of her?

question: You have beautiful skin... her skin was polka-dotted.
When we were kids we called her "Spot".

No. Not by me... I didn't go look. She wanted to meet someone new. I asked her "why?" -- she said, "Because he won't know me from before. Just now. Just what I am now." I knew her... on playgrounds... in Sunday School... all those grades -- I knew her as she changed. But she was still the same person. All the times I knew her, she was still her. She can't get away from that. You stay in one place, and all those things that are you... are there. She didn't understand that if you leave, they're still there, in you -- but they stop being clear. You stop knowing who you are, and what you want.
answer: You've stayed here and you know who you are?

question: I see the lawns I mow, houses I've painted, faces I know... my parents... And I'm constantly reminded of who I am.
answer: And you know what you want.

question: I want to be inside you.
answer: Good. Come here and put it inside me.

question: No... I want to be able to put myself inside of you.
answer: Doing this is as close as you get. Come here.

question: What do you want?
answer: I want... I want... Come inside me.

question: Hi.
answer: I didn't want to wake you.

question: I'm awake. I'm a morning person.
Then why don't you come back to bed?
What?
answer: I'd be so much happier if I could blame this on Nick, but it always happens to me. I'm always left with nothing. It doesn't matter if I leave the guy or if the guy leaves me -- I'm left with nothing. I never do anything for myself. I never acquire anything. I mean Nick didn't take from me. He stole a t.v. and left it for me. He didn't take my things, he didn't take our things... he didn't even take his clothes! And I'll still leave this house with nothing!

question: He took three years from you.
answer: No... He didn't take 'em. I mean, when he cared about me, he cared about me. And he was really good in bed. I didn't expect more.

question: Beth...
answer: I can't face this. I'm gonna finish up the kitchen... ...get some momentum...

question: A little weak on tenderness, but long on juice?
Good. So what are we doing?
answer: Christ... I gotta get out here. I was in Tucson two years before you and Nick got here. I've been here five years...

question: So what are you gonna do?
I've got some.
answer: I can't take it. I mean you're being great, but I can't take it. I'm gonna be gone, we won't see each other, and I won't send the money. I won't. I know... I won't get around, I'll forget, I won't do it. Shit. I'll sell all this shit. I don't want any of it, just my car and my clothes...

question: Okay...
answer: I'm sorry... I shouldn't have fucked this kid last night. I should have slept. Now I've got all this stuff to do, and I'm tired, I'm churned up, I'm in a fuckin' mood.

question: Let's do things, get you busy.
You get all the stuff you wanna sell, and I'll make some tag sale signs.
answer: No one'll buy my stuff. It's all junk.

question: That's what people buy at tag sales. Broken appliances, ugly knicknacks.
answer: I guess I do have stuff to sell.

question: Yes. Actually everything... I don't have anything.
I just moved to town. My husband passed away, and I, umm, didn't want to have our things... they were too familiar.
answer: You can have it all for three hundred. The stuff in these boxes and everything inside.

question: Oh, my, I don't know... everything?
answer: Everything. Except the t.v. The t.v.s not for sale.

question: I'll be right along. This had to be history's most efficient tag sale.
answer: Yeah... I'm sorry Sid stuck you with unloading.

question: No problem. He kinda bites my butt, but he's okay.
answer: He is. Listen. I'll probably be gone before you get back.

question: I thought maybe we could be roomies for a while. You know, while you figure out what's next.
answer: I can't. He gets to me... too much. If I don't go I'll end up with staying with him.

question: I'm sorry about selling the sofa bed.
answer: I didn't really need one. When my friends get drunk, they throw up and sleep on the floor.

question: But I gave it to you.
answer: You gave me a lot more.

question: No. It was all even in this department.
I know... You're hard again.
answer: I want you all the time.

question: Shit. I just fleeced a widow.
It was all junk. Shit. I've got to get some aspirin... I didn't drink enough to be hung over.
answer: You just feel bad for her like I feel bad for her... 'cause her husband died.

question: Yeah?
answer: That's about the saddest thing there is... losing someone you love.

question: It's never happened to me.
answer: If you died, I couldn't stand life.

question: I've got to go now. The new people'll be here.
No. I gotta get out.
answer: I can talk to the realtors, I know they've got a place in Agawam.

question: No... Agawam?... no. I don't know where I'm going. Somewhere else.
answer: You can call me when you get there. I'll give you my number.

question: Sid. I'm going away. You're making me way too important. You met me yesterday.
Jesus... one day...
answer: That doesn't matter. You know that. It can take a second.

question: No! That's... that's a fuckin' animal thing, I've done that.
I meet men, go home with them and just stay. No decision involved -- it's just what I do. And then I don't have to live my life, I just lead theirs. I can't keep doing that.
It's been passionate, it's been comfortable. But it hasn't been... important. Like you're making it!
answer: It is important! You know that.

question: No! It was a night! It wasn't real. It was fun, it was some great fucking! But it's just something that happened! It's not real!
answer: It didn't "just happen"! You know we're it! I'm the one for you!

question: The "one"?! I've had lots of "ones"! I look like a baby but I'm twenty- fuckin'-- eight years old! You're just the latest!
answer: No. I'm the last. You've found me. And it can go on forever.

question: No! Oh, Sid... Forever? You have to understand -- it's just talk.
It is. C'mon, these things you say... c'mon! What?! If I died you couldn't stand life? That's... that's...
No. You won't know when I die. You won't be there.
answer: You'd want me there. If I wasn't there it wouldn't matter who was. You'd be alone.

question: No!
answer: How do you feel? Think! You love me.

question: I care about you.
answer: You have to be with me.

question: No. I care about you. But I'm an adult. I can say no.
answer: That's what makes you an adult?

question: Yes. I can say no. No, I won't do that. No, I won't have that. No, I can't.
answer: You can say no to me?

question: Don't tell me what to do.
Shit! Excuse me. Shiiiiit!! Who are you?
I got that. Where'd she go?
Be at Carol's... be at Carol's... I'm too late... This really bothers me!
answer: Will you do me a favor?

question: Listen! I don't want to be normal. I don't have to be, I don't! This is my house. You're in my house. And I'm tired of going to my house and finding strangers!
answer: It's not your house. You're gone. I'm painting -- -- for the new people -- whose house it's going to be. You're gone. They're not here yet. I'm here. I guess that makes this my house.

question: Too bad.
answer: She didn't seem to want it.

question: That's foolish. That t.v. is a remarkable thing.
No. Do you know where she went?
Jesus! The next day! That's the world, huh? They don't even wait a day anymore.
No... I didn't leave her for another person, I left her for another place. Which I think is a little more excusable.
Well it's none of your fuckin' business!
Cause you fucked her? No! That gives you no business in my life.
answer: If you hadn't gone, I'd be done by now. I'd be home.

question: Be glad you have a home, asshole!
Why?!
answer: He was nice to Beth when you treated her like shit.

question: I came back...
answer: Nick. This is me. You didn't come back for Beth's sake -- something just didn't work out like you had planned.

question: You see -- you don't know everything about me -- I didn't really have any real plans!
answer: He was sweet to her. They were sweet with each other. Beth looked young with him. They had a real connection.

question: And I brought them together? It seems I'm blessed... in what I do. I do wrong, and it turns out right... that I've done right. So it really doesn't matter what I do. Hey! I said "hey!" I hope you're very happy together!
She is, isn't she? If you two were such the happy couple why the fuck did she leave, Romeo?
answer: After three years with you, she wanted to be alone.

question: I was already gone! This is not about me and Beth, there is no me and Beth! This is about you! Why didn't you go with her?
People aren't going to offer you anything! You have to take what you want.
answer: You can't take another person. They have to give themselves to you.

question: That's very wise, but not very true. I sell televisions. People don't know what they want. You have to show them.
No. He's not alone, he's with us. She's alone. She's out there alone. Just hoping she's closer to what she wants...

I don't know! How would I know?! What do I know?! I know that what I want isn't there. It isn't here. It isn't inside! It isn't outside! It doesn't exist. But you want her, and you aren't doing shit about it!
answer: There isn't anything he can do.

question: What kind of man won't fuck up his life for the women he loves? Go find her!!
answer: He wouldn't know where to look.

question: She'd she'd she'd... She'd head for her parents!

She'd head for her parents. Believe me. They're in Florida. That's east. You start driving east on route forty. Keep going east and around eleven start checking every roadside motel. The budget ones... You do that all night, you'll find her.
answer: How do you know she's on the highway?
